awd_titl_txt: Zip to Industry:  A First-Year Corporate-STEM Connection Program
awd_abstract_narration:
The importance of the "Zip to Industry" project is that it provides an opportunity for research on how job shadowing impacts student retention in STEM during the first year of college. Many freshman students in engineering or STEM majors have little understanding of what an engineer or STEM major does upon graduation.  The project will identify students who may have a weak connection to STEM careers upon entering and provide them with job shadowing experiences during their first year.  These first-year students will be paid for this exploration experience and can choose broadly or narrowly within STEM or engineering positions. The students will shadow current University of Akron students on co-operative education or internship placements. If successful, the project will be replicated at other colleges and universities, which can help increase the retention of students within STEM fields.  Sustainability plans are twofold: 1) should outcome goals on retention be reached through the project, the institution will fund the project coordinator position to run the program and 2) participating regional industry partners agree to be part of a consortium to support funding of the first-year students to participate.

The project's goal is to identify and recruit 2 cohorts of 50 STEM majors (totaling 100 students), explore their perceptions and knowledge of STEM careers, as well as their motivation for STEM careers. The students will have 10 job shadowing experiences during their first year.  The students will be trained in relevant professional development skills prior to leaving for their job sites and will have the ability to reflect on their experiences through focus group discussions and individual reflection. The educational framework for the "Zip to Industry" project is Social Cognitive Career Theory, which proposes that a person's goals and efforts towards realizing those goals, are impacted by their interest, confidence, outcome expectations and prior learning experiences related to the goal.  Job shadowing is conceived as a powerful learning experience that will impact knowledge and attitudes important for persistence toward a career goal. The University of Akron, which has the 5th oldest co-operative education program in the US, placed more than 1000 students in co-operative education/internship programs this past year.  With this extensive employer network, the mechanism exists at UA to examine the impact of a job shadowing program on first-year STEM students and improve retention in STEM fields.

por.por_cntn:
This project developed an intervention to increase the exposure of first-year students to STEM careers through job shadowing experiences at local companies in STEM industries. This exposure is important earlier in students' programs, as many students enter STEM majors at universities with little knowledge of careers in these fields and may become discouraged if they encounter challenges in their coursework, which impacts persistence. Through this program, three cohorts of first-year STEM students were paired with a mentor currently enrolled in co-operative education experience as a junior or senior at the university. The first two years of the program were in-person job shadowing, and the third year was adapted to a virtual experience due to the Covid19 pandemic. The program involved 136 first-year students over the three years, with a total of 326 job shadowing visits at over 60 companies. The in-person job shadowing experiences lasted half a day and included activities such as a tour of the company, observing various tasks at the company, and discussions with mentors about skills needed to succeed in STEM careers, as well as learning about the specific STEM industry at the company.  

The team conducted a mixed methods study to evaluate the impact of the program on students' outcomes. Pre and post surveys were administered to each cohort of students, and a comparison group of similar academic profile (major, ACT scores, GPA) and demographics was identified from the university database of first year students. In addition, focus group interviews were conducted yearly to gather data on program impact. Results of the study indicate that students who participated in the job shadowing program were retained in STEM programs at a higher rate than a comparison group. These results were observed for all three years of the program, including during the virtual intervention. In addition, students across all three cohorts found the program to be valuable to learn about STEM industries and reported that participating in job shadowing increased their interest in remaining in their majors. 

Results from this project were disseminated through conference presentations and proceedings from the American Society for Engineering Education. Furthermore, a structure for job shadowing experiences for first-year students was developed at the institution that can be adapted and replicated at other institutions who are interested in expanding exposure to STEM careers early in students' programs.
